Visualization of larynx was done using fibreoptic laryngoscopy which revealed Stage T3 supraglottic laryngeal cancer. Total laryngectomy was selected as a treatment option and the patient was admitted for preoperative evaluation. How do you describe Stage T3 of supraglottic laryngeal cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: Tumour limited to one subsite of supraglottis with normal vocal cord mobility

options.label: B
options.text: Tumour invades through the thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx

options.label: C
options.text: Tumour limited to larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades any of the following: postcricoid area, pre-epiglottic tissues, paraglottic space and/or minor thyroid cartilage invasion

options.label: D
options.text: Tumour invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures

questions.correct_answer: C. Tumour limited to larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades any of the following: postcricoid area, pre-epiglottic tissues, paraglottic space and/or minor thyroid cartilage invasion
questions.explanation:
Definition of TNM
Primary Tumor (T)
TX Primary tumor cannot be assessed
TO No evidence of primary tumor
Tis Carcinoma in situ
Supra glottis
T1 Tumor limited to one subsite of supraglottis with normal vocal cord ability
T2 Tumor invades mucosa of more than one adjacent subsite of supraglottis or glottis or region outside the supraglottis (e.g., mucosa of base of tongue, vallecula, medial wall or pyriform sinus) without fixation of the larynx
T3 Tumor limited to larynx with vocal cord fixation or invades any of the following: postcricoid area, pre-epiglottic tissues, paraglottic space, or minor thyroid cartilage erosion (e.g., inner cortex)
T4a Tumor invades through the thyroid cartilage or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. tracha, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of the tongue, strap muscles, thyroid, or esophagus)
T4b Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery, or invades mediastina I structures
Glottis
T1 Tumor limited to the vocal cord(s) (may involve anterior or posterior commissure) with normal mobility
T1a Tumor limited to one vocal cord
T1b Tumor involves both vocal cords
T2 Tumor extends to supraglottis or subglottis, or with impaired vocal cord mobility
T3 Tumor limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation or invades paraglottic space, or minor thyroid cartilage erosion (e.g., inner cortex)
T4a Tumor invades through the thyroid cartilage or invades tissues beyond the larynx (te.g, trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of the tongue, strap muscles, thyroid, or esophagus)
T4b Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery, or invades mediastinal structures

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy, who went on a camping trip in the mountains of Ohio a week ago with his family, is brought to the emergency department because of a headache, rash, and the abrupt onset of high fever for 2 days. The rash began on his palms and soles but spread to his ankles and arms. On physical examination, he has palpable purpura on his wrists and lower legs. The infection is likely caused by?
questions.explanation:
Rocky Mountain spotted fever Treponema pallidum Coxsackievirus Disseminated Histoplasmosis
  • RASH evolves as erythematous blanchable macules, papules, and petechiae
  • Appear 3 or 4 days later
  • Initially, over wrists and ankles
  • Spreads centrally to the limbs, trunk, and face
  • PALM-SOLES usually involved
  • Other findings: palatal petechiae, periorbital edema, acute abdomen

 

 
  • Eruptions are macular rashes and symmetrically distributed, almost always involving the face and forehead (individual lesions tend to be indurated; the colour may vary considerably, most often presenting as a subdued red rather than a bright red lesion)
  • Papules on the genitalia or within the oral cavity
  • Papular lesions on the palms of the hands or the soles of the feet
  • Generalized pustular or follicular lesions
  • Generalized lymphadenopathy

 

 

 

 

 
  • Mouth or throat pain secondary to the enanthem.
  • Vesicles surrounded by a thin halo of erythema eventually rupture and form superficial ulcers with a grey-yellow base surrounded by an erythematous rim.
  • The exanthem can be macular, vesicular, or papular. The lesions are non-pruritic and typically not painful.
  • The exanthem occurs on the dorsum of hands, feet, buttocks, legs, and arms.

 
  • Characteristic lesions include nodules, papules, plaques, ulcers, vesicles, pustules, abscesses, and generalized dermatitis.
  • Less commonly, exfoliative erythroderma, necrotizing vasculitis, cellulitis, panniculitis, petechiae, purpura, and ecchymosis can be seen

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy who committed a crime was brought by a constable for a check-up before taking him to Juvenile Detention Centre. Your senior doctor has examined the patient and marked his sexual maturity status as Tanner stage 3. Out of the following statements which is/are true regarding the Tanner stage III? Hair growth darker, coarser, and curried across the man's pubis Darkening of scrotum The glans (head) of the penis becomes more prominent The penis grows in length and the testes and scrotum continue to grow Genitalia reaches adult size and shape
questions.explanation:
Classification of sexual maturity status in boys:

Stage 1:

  • Prepubertal
  • No public hair and genitals proportionally the same as in childhood.

Stage 2:

  • Sparse hair growth at the base of the penis- slightly darkened
  • Scrotum and testes enlarge, Scrotum thins and reddens.

Stage 3:

  • Hair growth darker, coarser, and curried across the man's pubis
  • The penis grows in length and the testes and scrotum continue to grow

Stage 4:

  • Hair growth denser; coarse and curly like in an adult, but not yet spread to inner thighs
  • The penis continues to grow; the glans (head) of the penis becomes more prominent
  • The scrotum darkens.

Stage 5:

  • Hair growth extends to the inner thighs
  • Genitalia reaches adult size and shape.

questions.text: Read the following statements about Glycogen storage disorders: Type IV is due to Branching enzyme deficiency, which leads to progressive cirrhosis of the liver. Type I is due to alpha 1-4 glucosidase enzyme deficiency and it leads to severe hypoglycemia and massive enlargement of the liver. Type V is due to glycogen phosphorylase deficiency and leads to painful muscle cramps. Type II is due to alpha 1-4 deficiency and it is associated with Cardiomyopathy. Type III is due to Branching enzyme deficiency and it leads to milder hypoglycemia Identify the wrong statements:
questions.explanation:
type name Enzyme deficiency Organ Clinical features
I Von Gierke's disease Glucose 6-phosphatase Liver, kidney, git
  • Glycogen accumulation in liver and kidney
  • Hypoglycemia lactic acidemiaketosis· hyperlipidemia
II Pompe's disease Lysosomal alpha-1,4 glucosidase (acid maltase) All organs
  • Glycogen accumulation in lysosome in all organ
  • The heart is mostly affected
  • Death occurs at an early age due to heart failure
III Cori's disease/ Limit Dextrinosis Amylo alpha-1,6-glucosidase (debranching enzyme) Liver muscles and heart
  • fasting hypoglycemia
  • hepatomegaly in infancy
  • accumulation of characteristics branched polysaccharides (limit dextrin)
  • muscles weakness
IV Anderson's disease/ Amylopectinosis Glucosyl 4-6 transferase(branching enzyme) Most tissue
  • A rare disease, glycogen with only a few branches accumulate; cirrhosis of the liver
  • Death before 5 years of age due to heart failure or liver failure
V McArdle's disease Muscle glycogen phosphorylase Skeletal tissue
  • Muscles glycogen is very high but it cannot be used during exercise.
  • Cannot perform strenuous exercise
  • Muscles cramps
  • Blood lactate and pyruvate do not increase after exercise
VI Her's disease Liver glycogen phosphorylase Liver
  • The liver is increased in size because liver glycogen cannot convert into glucose
  • Mild hypoglycemia and ketosis
  • Good prognosis
VII Tarui's disease Phosphofructokinase Skeletal muscles and RBC
  • Muscles cramps due to exercise
  • Blood lactate is elevated
  • Hemolysis occurs
